title: La nueva identidad
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. 

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan de manera monopÃ³lica.

Depende la red en la que interactuemos se pueden obtener diferentes facetas de nuestra identidad digital relacionada con nuestras conexiones, interacciones y contenido. Creemos que esta identidad es nuestra, pero de hecho no lo es. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre esta.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. El modelo de negocio no estÃ¡ basado en vender datos a publicistas.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. Por primera vez podemos ser dueÃ±os de nuestra informaciÃ³n digital, tener portabilidad y total control. No existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender a publicistas.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y web3 ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda esta informaciÃ³n, independiente de la app que podemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet. A diferencia de los modelos de negocio actuales, no van a poder explotar nuestra informaciÃ³n para publicidad ni inventar algoritmos viciosos para mantenernos mirando la pantalla.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos, entonces ahora somos dueÃ±os de por ejemplo nuestros certificados. Y si estÃ¡n en nuestra wallet, se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad, tambiÃ©n como lo puede ser tener un token o un NFT. La propiedad estÃ¡ muy relacionada a la identidad y ahora con propiedad digital vamos a ver el concepto de identidad digital volver a nacer, replantearse, patear el tablero y dar devuelta las cartas.

title: IVA e Impuestos: Definiciones Clave
body:
1. Â¿QuÃ© es el Impuesto al Valor Agregado (IVA)?
   El Impuesto al Valor Agregado (IVA) es un tipo de impuesto (indirecto) que se aplica, en principio, a todas las actividades comerciales que involucran la producciÃ³n y distribuciÃ³n de bienes y la prestaciÃ³n de servicios.
2. Â¿CuÃ¡ndo se estableciÃ³ en MÃ©xico?
   Fue establecido en 1980 y sustituyÃ³ al Impuesto Sobre Ingresos Mercantiles.
3. Â¿QuÃ© impuesto reemplazÃ³ inicialmente?
   Impuesto Sobre Ingresos Mercantiles.
4. Â¿QuÃ© ley regula este impuesto?

* Ley del Impuesto al Valor Agregado o Ley del IVA.

1. Â¿CuÃ¡les son los actos o actividades contemplados en esta Ley?
   \-Cuando:
   Vender bienes.
   Proporcionar servicios independientes.
   Otorgar el uso o goce temporal de bienes inmuebles.
   Bienes o servicios importados.
2. Â¿CuÃ¡l es la tasa impositiva general?

* El 16% es el tipo impositivo general.

1. Â¿QuÃ© otras tarifas estÃ¡n contempladas?

* La ley establece el IVA para un 16%, luego un 0% para algunos productos, servicios y actividades especificados y una tasa exenta (sin impuesto) para otros productos, servicios y actividades especificados.

1. Da algunos ejemplos de productos, servicios o actividades que tributan al 0%

* Algunas cosas que estÃ¡n gravadas con una tasa del 0% son por ejemplo animales y plantas que no estÃ¡n industrializados excepto el caucho, perros, gatos y especies pequeÃ±as como mascotas en el hogar. TambiÃ©n, medicamentos de patente y productos para alimentaciÃ³n (con algunas excepciones), hielo y no elaborados con gas o agua, salvo que la presentaciÃ³n sea en envases inferiores a diez litros.

1. DÃ© algunos ejemplos de productos, servicios o actividades que no estÃ¡n sujetos a este impuesto (exentos)

* Son cosas exentas el suelo, construcciones adosadas al suelo destinadas o destinadas a habitaciÃ³n de vivienda. Libros, diarios y revistas, asÃ­ como el derecho de uso o explotaciÃ³n de una obra. Billetes y otros vales que permitan participar en loterÃ­as, rifas, sorteos o juegos.

Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan de manera monopÃ³lica.

Depende la red en la que interactuemos se pueden obtener diferentes facetas de nuestra identidad digital relacionada con nuestras conexiones, interacciones y contenido. Creemos que esta identidad es nuestra, pero de hecho no lo es. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre esta.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. El modelo de negocio no estÃ¡ basado en vender datos a publicistas.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. Por primera vez podemos ser dueÃ±os de nuestra informaciÃ³n digital, tener portabilidad y total control. No existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender a publicistas.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y web3 ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda esta informaciÃ³n, independiente de la app que podemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet. A diferencia de los modelos de negocio actuales, no van a poder explotar nuestra informaciÃ³n para publicidad ni inventar algoritmos viciosos para mantenernos mirando la pantalla.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que usemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

title: How did I Save 70000 ETH and Win 6 Million Bug Bounty
body:
Hi! I am [pwning.eth](https://twitter.com/PwningEth), a wanderer in the hacking space who has recently jumped into the wonderland of crypto. A few months ago, I reported a critical bug in the Aurora Engine, a layer 2 EVM solution built on the NEAR protocol. At least 70000 ETH were at risk of being stolen, until I found the tricky vulnerability and helped the Aurora team fix it. It would be in the [top 5](https://rekt.news/leaderboard/) heists in the defi history, if the 200 million tokens were taken over by a blackhat hacker. In the end, I won a bug bounty of 6 million, which was the second highest bounty in history.

I am an experienced whitehat hacker from the web2 world. I have been watching the hacking drama in the crypto world for a while, and there is so much randomness! I am not too surprised at the astronomical profits of defi hackers, because the criminals in the real world also make an insane amount of money. However, I was really shocked by the [story](https://www.saurik.com/optimism.html) of saurik, a famous hacker in the jailbreak community. The size of his bug bounty is unheard of in the traditional security world, and so I canâ€™t wait to start my own treasure hunt in web3.

I started by checking the bounty list on Immunefi. The [Aurora bounty program](https://immunefi.com/bounty/aurora/), listed on the very top of the website due to its huge bounty offer, caught my eye. It was a novel project built by a group of talented engineers, which suggested that it might be complex enough to be immune to common defi hackers and mysterious enough for me to learn something magical. Thanks to my experiences in hacking modern complex systems, I was able to start my research on the new blockchains quickly. I had reviewed the Aurora bridge, which was a solid project. Then I moved on to the Aurora engine and discovered the unicorn bug in a few hours. Unlike ordinary defi vulnerabilities, I didn't think this bug could be identified by random people as fast or lucky as me, so I took my time verifying and reproducing the bug in case it was a false alarm. It took me a few days to learn, build, learn, test and finally finish the report.

I tried pinging the Aurora team in discord, sending messages to the official bounty email and submitting the issue through Immunefi. They confirmed and patched the vulnerability quickly, and have since recounted the general [story](https://aurora.dev/blog/aurora-mitigates-its-inflation-vulnerability). Their rewards for smart contract critical vulnerabilities are calculated as 10% of potential economic damage of their exploitation, up to a value of $6,000,000 USD. In this case, the potential damage could have been higher than ten times this maximum reward. Therefore I was eligible to receive the maximum possible amount, the total value of $6,000,000 USD, in the form of locked AURORA tokens. Itâ€™s a pretty smart and lucky move to be listed on Immunefi :)

The [technical details](https://medium.com/immunefi/aurora-infinite-spend-bugfix-review-6m-payout-e635d24273d) have been explained by Immunefi. Here is my short summary:

1. The Aurora engine implements token bridging in prebuilt contracts at hardcoded addresses. They are the magical bridges connecting Ethereum, NEAR and Aurora.
2. The vulnerable contract always emits a fixed address in bridging events, assuming the `msg.value` will be collected by itself. However, if the contract is invoked by `delegatecall()`, the `msg.value` will never be sent to the contract but the log will be emitted as usual.
3. By repeating the malicious withdrawal then redeposit process, the attacker can double their balance exponentially. The infinity inflation of ETH could have destroyed the whole ecosystem of Aurora: all 71k ETH in the `aurora` account could have been drained, and other valuable tokens could have been purchased by free ETH. (There were billions of TVL in the Aurora bridge.)

If you are hardcore enough, you may find the [original report and scripts](https://app.ardrive.io/#/drives/7ba902d8-d26a-4dad-99b8-807eaaf8d925?name=AURORA) interesting, enjoy!

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. El modelo de negocio no estÃ¡ basado en vender datos a publicistas.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y web3 ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda esta informaciÃ³n, independiente de la app que podemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que utilicemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n.

Non lo nascondo: lâ€™idea di non essere censurato in alcun modo *mi piace*. Direi che mi piace anche lungo direttrici un tantino anarchiche e solleticanti. Possiamo fare molto di piÃ¹. Possiamo comunicare molto di piÃ¹.

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. No se requiere completar inÃºtiles formularios de registros.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y web3 ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda esta informaciÃ³n, independiente de la app que podemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que utilicemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n.

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. *No se requiere completar inÃºtiles formularios de registros*.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y web3 ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda la informaciÃ³n de cada app que utilicemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que utilicemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n.

title: What Are Subnet, ParaChain and ParaTime and Whatâ€™s Their Use?
body:
![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*M5StHJl5uYd9Q7PRLKaTww.jpeg)

If youâ€™ve been exploring the myriad of blockchain platforms on this planet, you might encounter these three terms.

* [Avalanche Subnet](https://chainstack.com/avalanche-subnet-tutorial-what-is-the-subnet/)
* [Polkadot Parachain](https://www.leewayhertz.com/what-is-polkadot-parachain/)
* [Oasis ParaTime](https://docs.oasis.dev/general/oasis-network/overview/)

## What Are They And Why We Need Them?

Broadly speaking, they are features that allow you to run your own â€œlittleâ€ blockchain on top of each particular blockchain.

You see, the issue with blockchain is scalability. Thatâ€™s why you and I are paying our asses off when we are using Ethereum because everyoneâ€™s pushing to store or validate their data on each block and it could only support a limited amount of transactions per second (like 21 TPS). The miners feel since they only could validate so few transactions at a time, they deserve to be paid more so they pick to process transactions that are willing to pay more gas fees versus those with cheap gas fees. The amount of this fee is usually painful to bear due to this bottleneck.

Moreover, many experts feel that we canâ€™t truly scale a blockchain to kingdom come with just one single chain, regardless of whatever complexity one throws into it. Thus, the other logical alternative is to split into multiple chains.

So, these subchains are like little blockchains that sit on top of the parent or mother chain, if you will.

So, instead of everyone trying to get mother to work, each has their own little chain to use.

I hope this explains it in a layman's way. Iâ€™ve cherry-picked some easy-to-understand links above that point to more details on how each mini-chain is different than the other.

![You can actually create an EVM subnet on Avalanche and Oasis.](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*36FEPlg1xqbyrEn2TucbXw.png)

## Which Is Best?

Your guess is as good as mine. Each of them does come with its own bells and whistles, some subchains include a consensus layer while some donâ€™t and some have different types of subchains â€” privacy and EVM minichains. [Moonbeam](https://moonbeam.network/), for instance, is an EVM for Polkadot network built on parachain. This means it allows you to run your Solidity smart contract on Polkadot.

Iâ€™ve yet to find time to dig deep into each of them but Iâ€™d say it depends on what dapp you wish to build.

If youâ€™ve used any of the parallel chains we discussed, please share your experience in the comments below.

*Disclaimer: Iâ€™m in no way affiliated with any of the blockchain platforms mentioned.*

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. *No se requiere completar inÃºtiles formularios de registros*.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y web3 ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda la informaciÃ³n de cada app que utilicemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que usemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n y el valor econÃ³mico que se genera este mejor distribuido entre sus participantes.

title: The end of signups
body:
Every time we grab the cell phone we are losing money. We are voluntarily providing our attention and information to some private company which then exploits, manipulates and monetizes it without our consent. Each platform owns all of our digital information and we cannot exercise any rights over it.

On the internet that we know, modern digital banks (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon) took advantage of timing and their unlimited resources of investment funds to offer us convenience (cheap software) in exchange for our attention and information. Their valuations are directly proportional to the information they store. It is very similar to Banks in the sense that they control and exploit our money. 

Luckily web3 changes the paradigm. In this new era, users have control of their information, there are no centralized databases that can be sold or exploited. No need to fill out useless registration forms.

For example [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) is trying to bridge web2 and crypto by offering interfaces to integrate wallets with traditional applications. The wallet login implies that our information is public, portable and protected by cryptography. If we interact with a certain network and then log in to another, the accumulated information is ours and we can use it in a new network.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OCLBY965FLmYkhASwMRxU.png?height=1206&width=2326)

In the [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) project, they created a specific protocol for social matters that allows developers to program decentralized applications with basic social functionalities such as uploading content (posts), sharing, liking, creating your profile and generating connections (the social graph). Theoretically, networks like Twitter or Instagram could be built on Lens. The interesting thing is that all the information of each app that we use will be associated with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B4XP1C5EXSIrE5TViJbZk.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) issues an NFT (a Poap) of every event we attend. The Poap remains in our wallet and therefore they become part of our identity. Other services that we use could offer us something based on the type of events that we attend for example, but only if we choose to log in with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a9LHxknamU_7Usi24QEO1.png?height=814&width=2198)

It will be interesting to see how technology evolves in the social field. Undoubtedly, better applications and digital networks will be generated where users participate with rights over their information and the economic value generated is better distributed among its participants.

title: DAO

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. *No se requiere completar inÃºtiles formularios de registros*.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y web3 ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda la informaciÃ³n de cada app que utilicemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que usemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n y el valor econÃ³mico que se genera este mejor distribuido entre sus participantes.

title: Behind the NFT: Alex Majoliâ€™s Guards Inside the Kremlin
body:
### Magnum 75 #21 by Alex Majoli. Moscow, Russia. 2019

[https://foundation.app/@magnumphotos/mpa75/21](https://foundation.app/@magnumphotos/mpa75/21)

In 2019, Alex Majoli traveled to Moscow, Russia to explore the city and document life in the Russian capital. One of the spaces he visited was the Kremlin, and this image above shows Kremlin guards lined up and ready for duty.

The project was part of the Magnum Live Lab initiative, which invites photographers to spend an intense two-week period in a host city, where they produce new work and take part in daily editing sessions.

> For Alex Majoli, the concept of the Live Lab suited him: â€œTo me, the Live Lab is a beautiful idea because we can have long-term projects and edit and re-edit and all this time to think. The fact we donâ€™t have time to think, thereâ€™s an immediate response â€“ thereâ€™s an essence of truth.â€

The photographer used the opportunity to continue exploring the theatrical approach that he had developed over ten years, demonstrated in photobooks such as *Scene*. Each day, he explored a facet of Moscow that he had a preconception of, ending with an editing session with curator Nina Gomiashvili.

> Though he had visited Moscow before his recent trip for the Live Lab, Alex Majoliâ€™s vision of the city had been built through literature and music, and this guided his eye when he hit the streets daily for an intense two-week shooting and editing project. â€œWhen I walk in the city of Moscow, I have the Bulgakov black cat in my mind,â€ he says of imagining every black cat he sees in the city could be the Behemoth from the novel The Master and Margarita.

This mode of exploring, looking for motifs we recognize from our own cultural reference points, is something we all do, says Majoli. â€œAn image will stimulate something already in you and develop,â€ he explains. â€œIn that sense, art is created in people.â€

To find out more about Alex Majoliâ€™s Moscow project, check out the full article here.

To find out more about Alex Majoli, click [here](https://www.magnumphotos.com/photographer/alex-majoli/)

title: Day 0
body: Up only.

title: The end of signups
body:
Every time we grab the cell phone we are losing money. We are voluntarily providing our attention and information to some private company which then exploits, manipulates and monetizes it without our consent. Each platform owns all of our digital information and we cannot exercise any rights over it.

On the internet that we know, modern digital banks (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon) took advantage of timing and their unlimited resources of investment funds to offer us convenience (cheap software) in exchange for our attention and information. It is very similar to Banks in the sense that they control and exploit our money. Their valuations are directly proportional to the information they store.

Luckily web3 changes the paradigm. In this new era, users have control of their information, there are no centralized databases that can be sold or exploited. No need to fill out useless registration forms.

For example [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) is trying to bridge web2 and crypto by offering interfaces to integrate wallets with traditional applications. The wallet login implies that our information is public, portable and protected by cryptography. If we interact with a certain network and then log in to another, the accumulated information is ours and we can use it in a new network.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OCLBY965FLmYkhASwMRxU.png?height=1206&width=2326)

In the [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) project, they created a specific protocol for social matters that allows developers to program decentralized applications with basic social functionalities such as uploading content (posts), sharing, liking, creating your profile and generating connections (the social graph). Theoretically, networks like Twitter or Instagram could be built on Lens. The interesting thing is that all the information of each app that we use will be associated with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B4XP1C5EXSIrE5TViJbZk.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) issues an NFT (a Poap) of every event we attend. The Poap remains in our wallet and therefore they become part of our identity. Other services that we use could offer us something based on the type of events that we attend for example, but only if we choose to log in with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a9LHxknamU_7Usi24QEO1.png?height=814&width=2198)

It will be interesting to see how technology evolves in the social field. Undoubtedly, better applications and digital networks will be generated where users participate with rights over their information and the economic value generated is better distributed among its participants.

title: Designing the Elfiverse
body:
The worlds of NFTs and DeFi have generally stayed separate, experiencing only minimal cross-pollination. At Element, we believe there is fertile ground at their intersection, ripe with fresh and exciting ideas waiting to be unearthed.

NFTs are an artistic medium of visual and creative expression that we wanted to bring to users of DeFi protocols. Users naturally craft experiences and design a vibrant story in their protocol and community interactions, well beyond their portfolio balance.

The birth of the Elfiverse was born from the desire to weave Element community members into a world of visual storytelling that increases ownership and belonging in a rich DeFi universe.

## Design Inspiration

In designing the Elfiverse, we wanted to bring to life the concept of being a living breathing Elf inhabiting the Element ecosystem (Element.fi or El.fi for short, get it?). The actions that users take in the Protocol had to be visualized in a way that could be compelling to the viewer, while also portraying the key elements of the Protocolâ€™s story.

We gathered inspiration from movies, TV shows, and video games that describe the elements of elvish and medieval culture that we wanted to bring to life. Games such as Runescape gave us valuable examples of the different crafting and inventory systems that we wanted to explore. Games of Thrones was also a good point of inspiration in crafting the different environments to make them seem grand and lived in.

When crafting the scenes in 3D, visual composition plays an integral part. For example, to visualize how vast the Elfiverse is, different depth of field & atmospheric effects are used to craft large enough landscapes and environments to fully capture the expanse of the world. To really show the roughness & ferociousness of the Sea of Liquidity, we created a more violent ocean & darkened the sky with thunder clouds, depicting the treacherous journey to this new land.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/pcQY6aogwiN40UgMUrLH7.png?height=2839&width=6341)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/qRUGZYK8pRsp9UERUvskL.png?height=2908&width=6439)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eL4wxw_iFEs_2WQYYwz3Q.png?height=2858&width=6402)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eCCfru7pAnKeK3xMHlumz.png?height=2872&width=6280)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eD1xATfQakA1t7qGiJrh2.png?height=2917&width=6371)

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/49qaOfl3gJ_DG0N1UYwgg.png?height=2949&width=6412)

### Asset Creation

Throughout the creation of this project, we used a collection of assets that were created using pixelated components in Figma. An asset library of over 150 assets was created to be generated with a script to create unique random outputs, resulting in the Elfiverse collection of 10,000 ELF NFTs.

The asset library started with backgrounds, created with *Cinema 4D*, visualizing the regional ecosystem for environments that spanned across the Elfiverse. These rich environmental tapestries acted as a scaffold upon which a vibrant visual narrative could come to life, with fictional characters whose arcs closely mirrored our own.

### Crafting the Backgrounds

As we started to craft the 3D environments, we curated virtual environments that validated the original story components. As an example, the characters of the Elfiverse were continuously traveling and venturing on a journey to build and find fulfilling goods to bring their ideas to fruition.

The first component was a set of portals that acted as intermediaries traveling between different parts of the world that were used to segment the different worlds based on the storyline. This included â€˜Clear Skiesâ€™ that signaled peace and tranquility and â€˜Blood Riversâ€™ that were shown to those with a future of battle or strife.

### Building Out A Grid System

With the generation of the assets, we had to build out a grid layer system so that the assets being exported were carefully crafted in an order that showcased all the possible accessories and features the ELF NFT could have. Creating an array of elves that instituted a variety of appearances, personalities and a multitude of emotions was our priority.

The grid layer system was designed *32 pixels by 32 pixels* and originated with different skin tones, weapons, clothes, hair, mouth, eyebrows, eyes, hats, eyewear, add-ons. Ranging from *green body skin* to *red body skin*, each body asset was exported as the first layer from the original *drawLayer* function in our regeneration script.

### Designing the classes and accessories

As the ELF characterâ€™s journey and environments were being refined we aimed to define a class of elves that mirrored our community and our team. The five different foundational classes crafted were Adventurer, Warrior, Ranger, Cleric, and Mage. These classes were created by the accessories that defined them. These accessories were created in Photoshop and then added to our square layer grid.

### The Generation

We built on top of an open source [NFT generation script](https://github.com/HashLips/generative-art-node) from HashLips, which gives you all you need to launch your own generative NFT project.

Of course, we added some Elf-specific twists:

* Separate randomness calculation from asset creation, to allow for testing
* Fine-grained assets and descriptions are stored in a csv for easy editing
* Debugging code to identify clashing color combinations
* Test statistical randomness of outcomes
* A meta-property defined by the NFTâ€™s assets (your Elfâ€™s class)

This enabled us to do quality control on specific outcomes, like generating 100 NFTs all with red background and red hair: does it look good? We decided to keep most of these in, including eyebrows that are a different color from your hair (that Elf used dye from dank strains).

We also built this [light-weight spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1pFRExUjpPH8Va2UOyenMko966gNBKVW9PHmTKgzPxoA/edit#gid=197483786) to inspect the details of your Elf ([this repo](https://github.com/mihai6/nft-analyst-starter-pack) updates it, forked from [@DarenMatsuoka](https://twitter.com/DarenMatsuoka)). It lists each asset that comprises your NFT, including their description (not shown on other sites), which places your Elf uniquely in the lore of the Elfiverse. Rarity score uses a [very standard calculation](https://raritytools.medium.com/ranking-rarity-understanding-rarity-calculation-methods-86ceaeb9b98c) per asset, then added up for your NFT.

## Whatâ€™s Next

More recently weâ€™ve open sourced our [ELFI contracts](https://github.com/element-fi/nft-contracts) that allow community members to build on top of our existing NFT infrastructure. Weâ€™re excited to see what opening up to the Elfiverse for potential collaborations and contributions means for the project.

It's time for the Element community to decide what to build on top of the existing NFT infrastructure. This is an exciting opportunity for designers, developers, and creatives to discuss how to expand the Elfiverse ecosystem. The possibilities are endless.

In the coming weeks, we will be rolling out more content to cover the different aspects of the Elfiverse. This will include:

* A Technical Deep Dive & Architecture Overview of the Elfiverse NFT Contracts
* An Open Source Elfiverse & What It Means as a Builder or Designer. Considerations around the future of Elfiverse & Element DAO, and ideas to explore.
* Transfer of the remaining Elfiverse ELF NFTs to the Element DAO Treasury

Weâ€™re excited about the future of the Elfiverse and want to hear from you! Join the #community discord and the Elfiverse [forum channel](https://forum.element.fi/discussions/7.%20Elfiverse) and get involved in the discussion.

title: Another EMBRANDT Sounds Mix
body:
I put together a mix as a celebration of the start of summer and beating my creative block ğŸ‘ haha! Itâ€™s a great feeling to be back in the sun rays and the cold air-conditioned buildings of the city. Biking around the city has been fun, too - the best part is summer is just getting started. 

I wanted to share what I was feeling lately; this mix is a representation of a bigger playlist of about 60 songs. I like to take my time exploring my SoundCloud and Audius feeds and add my favorite tunes to a playlist. From there, I listen to the playlist as I add to it and feel for a vibe in the songs. 

Whether itâ€™s the algorithm feeding me the vibes or my honest interpretation of all the music I hear, I hope you enjoy the sounds. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022)

More on how I think about and how I make my mixes below.

Tracklist: Artist - Song

 1. [Deeper Purpose - Stop Trippin](https://soundcloud.com/deeperpurpose/stop-trippin)
 2. [Sliipow - Flashion](https://soundcloud.com/terminalunderground/flashion)
 3. [Born DIrty - Kiss](https://soundcloud.com/borndirtymusic/kiss-way-way-records)
 4. [Gustavo Koch - In Da Ghetto](https://soundcloud.com/housixrecords/gustavo-koch-in-da-ghetto-hsx004)
 5. [KZN - THE CLUB](https://soundcloud.com/blackartelrec/kzn-the-club)
 6. [Mochakk - Early Synths](https://soundcloud.com/mochakkmusic/mochakk-early-synths)
 7. [Taiki Nulight - Ugly Truth](https://soundcloud.com/confession/taiki-nulight-ugly-truth)
 8. [Twista - Overnight Celebrity (Qlank Remix)](https://soundcloud.com/qlank/twista-overnight-celebrity-qlank-remix)
 9. [Twogangs - Turma](https://soundcloud.com/goodtimesaheadmusic/twogangs-turma)
10. [Victor Cardenas & Meluchis - Boom Pa-Ra (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/fightclvb/boom-pa-ra)
11. [Doja Cat - Kiss Me Moreft. SZA (Gabe Ruth Rework)](https://soundcloud.com/gaberuthau/doja-cat-kiss-me-more-ft-sza-gabe-ruth-rework)
12. [Nicche - Metro](https://soundcloud.com/nicchefm/nicche-metroo)
13. [Buogo - Free](https://soundcloud.com/houseofhustle/hls339-buogo-free-original-mix)
14. [Destinyâ€™s Child - Lose My Breath (Alex Chapman House Edit)](https://soundcloud.com/alexchapman1/lose-my-breath-alex-chapman-edit)
15. [SNBRN - DMs ft. 1993, Lucati](https://soundcloud.com/snbrn/dms-feat-1993) 
16. [Kyle Walker - All You Need (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/kylewalkersongs/all-you-need-extended-mix)
17. [Endor - Heavyweight](https://soundcloud.com/endortracksuk/heavyweight)

### Mix Method-ology  |||  Whatâ€™s to a mix by me?

I like to think of myself as a music curator and not a DJ. 

A DJ is someone that knows how to use a mixer to move a crowd with music theyâ€™ve made or gathered.

Iâ€™m generally not interested in DJing in front of people (â€¦yet. Iâ€™m on the path to convincing myself to do it). Partly because Iâ€™m still kinda shy about it, but mostly because I like to play music *I like* for people. 

Itâ€™s more of a performance. 

We all go to festivals or shows and we take in the music they play out. Granted, the music they play is stuff they make themselves and they're all usually bangers. What matters most, from my perspective, is the quality of the music they play and less about how they mix it. 

In my quest to make a mix, I prioritize the diversity of sounds and bass over everything. I focus on finding some good sounds and let the rest come together. Songs nowadays are getting creative in their intros/outros/breakdowns; I use this idea to let me bypass getting too deep into effects and instead try to find good places to press play on the next song as clean as possible (though it may not always work out that way haha).

**How do you find music?** I follow a ton of people on [SoundCloud](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/following) so my feed is all over the place with different genres and tunes a day. I can press play and I trust Iâ€™ll hear a good song at least once every 2-4 songs. 

**What do you do when you find a song you like?** There are three options: like, repost, or playlist. I repost the ones I find more creative (aka nasty) and Iâ€™ll playlist the ones I enjoyed best from those. 

**What kind of playlists do you have?** We have our main [house](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_dance) and [dubstep](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_bass) playlists, a [Halloween](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/spoopy) dubstep playlist, [trippy bass sounds](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/trippy-edm) playlist. Depending on the song, Iâ€™ll add it to one of these playlists or Iâ€™ll only throw it into my mix playlist ğŸ˜ˆ haha. Kind of evil when my spirit is to share all the music, but thatâ€™s why I want to make these posts and include the link to the huge playlist so you can see where my ears were at. 

**Drop the link to the playlist!** Say less. Hereâ€™s the pool of music I worked with for the mix. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus)

**Why are some transitions bad (or too obvious) in your mixes?** I record my mixes in one take to simulate playing in front of people. I get the most practice playing the mix when I put the songs in order; the later half of my mixes are usually more freeform in terms of how theyâ€™re put together, whereas the first half is the more practiced bit. I mix with what Iâ€™ve picked up in the last year and the goal is to learn more tricks on the mixer now that Iâ€™m happy with the way Iâ€™m putting songs together. Itâ€™s a process and Iâ€™m happy to be documenting the progress. If youâ€™ve listened to one or all of the mixes Iâ€™ve made to date, know that youâ€™re early and itâ€™s only up from here with the quality.

title: Another EMBRANDT Sounds Mix
body:
I put together a mix as a celebration of the start of summer and beating my creative block ğŸ‘ haha! Itâ€™s a great feeling to be back in the sun rays and the cold air-conditioned buildings of the city. Biking around the city has been fun, too - the best part is summer is just getting started. 

I wanted to share what I was feeling lately; this mix is a representation of a bigger playlist of about 60 songs. I like to take my time exploring my SoundCloud and Audius feeds and add my favorite tunes to a playlist. From there, I listen to the playlist as I add to it and feel for a vibe in the songs. 

Whether itâ€™s the algorithm feeding me the vibes or my honest interpretation of all the music I hear, I hope you enjoy the sounds. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022)

More on how I think about and how I make my mixes below.

Tracklist: Artist - Song

 1. [Deeper Purpose - Stop Trippin](https://soundcloud.com/deeperpurpose/stop-trippin)
 2. [Sliipow - Flashion](https://soundcloud.com/terminalunderground/flashion)
 3. [Born DIrty - Kiss](https://soundcloud.com/borndirtymusic/kiss-way-way-records)
 4. [Gustavo Koch - In Da Ghetto](https://soundcloud.com/housixrecords/gustavo-koch-in-da-ghetto-hsx004)
 5. [KZN - THE CLUB](https://soundcloud.com/blackartelrec/kzn-the-club)
 6. [Mochakk - Early Synths](https://soundcloud.com/mochakkmusic/mochakk-early-synths)
 7. [Taiki Nulight - Ugly Truth](https://soundcloud.com/confession/taiki-nulight-ugly-truth)
 8. [Twista - Overnight Celebrity (Qlank Remix)](https://soundcloud.com/qlank/twista-overnight-celebrity-qlank-remix)
 9. [Twogangs - Turma](https://soundcloud.com/goodtimesaheadmusic/twogangs-turma)
10. [Victor Cardenas & Meluchis - Boom Pa-Ra (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/fightclvb/boom-pa-ra)
11. [Doja Cat - Kiss Me Moreft. SZA (Gabe Ruth Rework)](https://soundcloud.com/gaberuthau/doja-cat-kiss-me-more-ft-sza-gabe-ruth-rework)
12. [Nicche - Metro](https://soundcloud.com/nicchefm/nicche-metroo)
13. [Buogo - Free](https://soundcloud.com/houseofhustle/hls339-buogo-free-original-mix)
14. [Destinyâ€™s Child - Lose My Breath (Alex Chapman House Edit)](https://soundcloud.com/alexchapman1/lose-my-breath-alex-chapman-edit)
15. [SNBRN - DMs ft. 1993, Lucati](https://soundcloud.com/snbrn/dms-feat-1993) 
16. [Kyle Walker - All You Need (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/kylewalkersongs/all-you-need-extended-mix)
17. [Endor - Heavyweight](https://soundcloud.com/endortracksuk/heavyweight)

### Mix Method-ology  |||  Whatâ€™s to a mix by me?

I like to think of myself as a music curator and not a DJ. 

A DJ is someone that knows how to use a mixer to move a crowd with music theyâ€™ve made or gathered.

Iâ€™m generally not interested in DJing in front of people (â€¦yet. Iâ€™m on the path to convincing myself to do it). Partly because Iâ€™m still kinda shy about it, but mostly because I like to play music *I like* for people. 

Itâ€™s more of a performance. 

We all go to festivals or shows and we take in the music they play out. Granted, the music they play is stuff they make themselves and they're all usually bangers. What matters most, from my perspective, is the quality of the music they play and less about how they mix it. 

In my quest to make a mix, I prioritize the diversity of sounds and bass over everything. I focus on finding some good sounds and let the rest come together. Songs nowadays are getting creative in their intros/outros/breakdowns; I use this idea to let me bypass getting too deep into effects and instead try to find good places to press play on the next song as clean as possible (though it may not always work out that way haha).

**How do you find music?** I follow a ton of people on [SoundCloud](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/following) so my feed is all over the place with different genres and tunes a day. I can press play and I trust Iâ€™ll hear a good song at least once every 2-4 songs. 

**What do you do when you find a song you like?** There are three options: like, repost, or playlist. I repost the ones I find more creative (aka nasty) and Iâ€™ll playlist the ones I enjoyed best from those. 

**What kind of playlists do you have?** We have our main [house](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_dance) and [dubstep](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_bass) playlists, a [Halloween](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/spoopy) dubstep playlist, [trippy bass sounds](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/trippy-edm) playlist. Depending on the song, Iâ€™ll add it to one of these playlists or Iâ€™ll only throw it into my mix playlist ğŸ˜ˆ haha. Kind of evil when my spirit is to share all the music, but thatâ€™s why I want to make these posts and include the link to the huge playlist so you can see where my ears were at. 

**Drop the link to the playlist!** Say less. Hereâ€™s the pool of music I worked with for the mix. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus)

**Why are some transitions too obvious in your mixes?** I record my mixes in one take. I get most of my practice playing the mix when I put the songs in the order I want. I mix with what I know right now, but the goal is to start learning more transitions and effects now that Iâ€™m happy with the way Iâ€™m playing songs. Itâ€™s a process and Iâ€™m happy to be documenting the progress. If youâ€™ve listened to one or all of the mixes Iâ€™ve made, know that youâ€™re early and itâ€™s only up from here with the quality.

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. *No se requiere completar inÃºtiles formularios de registros*.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y crypto ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Lo interesante es que toda la informaciÃ³n de cada app que utilicemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que usemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n y el valor econÃ³mico que se genera este mejor distribuido entre sus participantes.

title: Hello

title: The end of signups
body:
Every time we grab the cell phone we are losing money. We are voluntarily providing care and information to some private company which then exploits, manipulates and monetizes it without our consent. Each platform owns all of our digital information and we cannot exercise any rights over it.

On the internet that we know, modern digital banks (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon) took advantage of timing and their unlimited resources of investment funds to offer us convenience in exchange for our attention and information. It is exactly the same thing that banks do with our money. Their valuations are directly proportional to the information they store.

Luckily web3 changes the paradigm. In this new era, users have control of their information, there are no centralized databases that can be sold or exploited. No need to fill out useless registration forms.

For example [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) is trying to bridge web2 and crypto by offering interfaces to integrate wallets with traditional applications. The wallet login implies that our information is public, portable and protected by cryptography. If we interact with a certain network and then log in to another, the accumulated information is ours and we can use it in a new network.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OCLBY965FLmYkhASwMRxU.png?height=1206&width=2326)

In the [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) project, they created a specific protocol for social matters that allows developers to program decentralized applications with basic social functionalities such as uploading content (posts), sharing, liking, creating your profile and generating connections (the social graph). Theoretically, networks like Twitter or Instagram could be built on Lens. The interesting thing is that all the information of each app that we use will be associated with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B4XP1C5EXSIrE5TViJbZk.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) issues an NFT (a Poap) of every event we attend. The Poap remains in our wallet and therefore they become part of our identity. Other services that we use could offer us something based on the type of events that we attend for example, but only if we choose to log in with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a9LHxknamU_7Usi24QEO1.png?height=814&width=2198)

It will be interesting to see how technology evolves in the social field. Undoubtedly, better applications and digital networks will be generated where users participate with rights over their information and the economic value generated is better distributed among its participants.

title: The end of signups
body:
Every time we grab the cell phone we are losing money. We are voluntarily providing our attention and information to some private company which then exploits, manipulates and monetizes it without our consent. Each platform owns all of our digital information and we cannot exercise any rights over it.

On the internet that we know, modern digital banks (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon) took advantage of timing and their unlimited resources of investment funds to offer us convenience (cheap software) in exchange for our attention and information. Their valuations are directly proportional to the information they store. It is very similar to Banks in the sense that they control and exploit our money. 

Luckily web3 changes the paradigm. In this new era, users have control of their information, there are no centralized databases that can be sold or exploited. No need to fill out useless registration forms.

For example [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) is trying to bridge web2 and crypto by offering interfaces to integrate wallets authentication with traditional applications. The wallet implies that our information is public, portable and protected by cryptography. If we interact with a certain network or dapp the accumulated information is ours and we can use it in a new network just by logging into it.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OCLBY965FLmYkhASwMRxU.png?height=1206&width=2326)

In the [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) project, they created a specific protocol for social networks that allows developers to program decentralized applications with basic social functionalities such as uploading content (posts), sharing, liking, creating your profile and generating connections (the social graph). Theoretically, networks like Twitter or Instagram could be built on Lens. The interesting thing is that all the information of each app that we use will be associated with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B4XP1C5EXSIrE5TViJbZk.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) issues an NFT (a Poap) of every event we attend. The Poap remains in our wallet and therefore they become part of our identity. Other services that we use could offer us something based on the type of events that we attend for example, but only if we choose to log in with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a9LHxknamU_7Usi24QEO1.png?height=814&width=2198)

It will be interesting to see how technology evolves in the social field. Undoubtedly, better applications and digital networks will be generated where users participate with rights over their information and the economic value generated is better distributed among its participants.

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. *No se requiere completar inÃºtiles formularios de registros*.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y crypto ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Toda la informaciÃ³n de cada app que utilicemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierten en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que usemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos comenzar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n y el valor econÃ³mico que se genera este mejor distribuido entre sus participantes.

title: The end of signups
body:
Every time we grab the cell phone we are losing money. We are voluntarily providing our attention and information to some private company which then exploits, manipulates and monetizes it without our consent. Each platform owns all of our digital information and we cannot exercise any rights over it.

On the internet that we know, modern digital banks (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon) took advantage of timing and their unlimited resources of investment funds to offer us convenience (cheap software) in exchange for our attention and information. Their valuations are directly proportional to the information they store. It is very similar to Banks in the sense that they control and exploit our money. 

Luckily web3 changes the paradigm. In this new era, users have control of their information, there are no centralized databases that can be sold or exploited. No need to fill out useless registration forms.

For example [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) is trying to bridge web2 and crypto by offering interfaces to integrate wallets authentication with traditional applications. The wallet implies that our information is public, portable and protected by cryptography. If we interact with a certain network or dapp the accumulated information is ours and we can use it in a new network just by logging into it.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OCLBY965FLmYkhASwMRxU.png?height=1206&width=2326)

The [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) team created a specific protocol for human digital networks that allows developers to program decentralized applications with basic social functionalities such as uploading content (posts), sharing, likes, creating your profile and generating connections (the social graph). Theoretically, networks like Twitter or Instagram could be built on Lens. All the information of each app that we use will be associated with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B4XP1C5EXSIrE5TViJbZk.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) issues an NFT (a Poap) of every event we attend. The Poap remains in our wallet and therefore they become part of our identity. Other services that we use could offer us something based on the type of events that we attend for example, but only if we choose to log in with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a9LHxknamU_7Usi24QEO1.png?height=814&width=2198)

It will be interesting to see how technology evolves in the social field. Undoubtedly, better applications and digital networks will be generated where users participate with rights over their information and the economic value generated is better distributed among its participants.
