title: Understanding the Lattice1 Security Mesh
body:
> *This is a publication of the [GridPlus Blog](https://blog.gridplus.io). It is written to the best of my technical knowledge but should not be taken as an absolutist stance on any technologies discussed herein.*


---

In a recent [Lattice](https://gridplus.io/products/grid-lattice1) firmware update ([v0.15.0](https://github.com/GridPlus/lattice-firmware-history#v0150)), GridPlus shipped a new feature allowing greater configuration of the deviceâ€™s most advanced hardware security feature: the **anti-tamper security mesh**. This new software feature allows the user to either â€œ**arm**â€ or â€œ**disarm**â€ the mesh. There has been some confusion about what this means and how it works, so in this article I will explain the purpose of the security mesh and how your data is secured by your Lattice.

> ***NOTE:*** *This is a fairly technical article with a lot of details. If you want a tl;dr version, you can read [this](https://docs.gridplus.io/lattice1/security-features#tamper-mesh).*

### What is an Anti-tamper SecurityÂ Mesh?

To my knowledge, the GridPlus Lattice1 is the only hardware wallet with a security mesh. We added this hardware component to turn an already secure device into something that we believe is significantly more secure than anything else the crypto industry has ever offered. We truly believe it is nearly impossible for even the most sophisticated attacker to access your Latticeâ€™s secure data without your PINâ€Šâ€”â€Šmuch of this assurance comes from the mesh.

![LDS Process](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/hndcw8rNxvgQ5jaDQ-gLd.webp?height=560&width=800)

[This article](https://www.aerodefensetech.com/component/content/article/adt/supplements/et/features/articles/14919) provides a great overview of how security meshes are manufactured using a Laser Directed Structuring (LDS) process. The tl;dr is that the mesh is made of a plastic polymer, which is engraved by a high-precision laser into a maze-like structure. When the laser hits the polymer, it not only makes a physical engraving, but also actives a catalyst in the plastic to make it highly reactive to copper plating, which is done in a second electrolysis step. The result is a plastic plate with extremely fine (\~5mm) copper lines running throughout. 
 

![Fine engravings plated with copper](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/D5P6xQCNbWP88QEKwkz6j.jpeg?height=377&width=800)

Copper is of course a highly conductive material so the engraved, plated mesh can now be hooked up to battery leads, at which point a current is run indefinitely through the maze structure. We use a simple coin cell battery in the Lattice, which can run continuous current through the device for 5 years or so with the Lattice unpowered (if the device is powered, the battery is rated for 20 years or more, as your wall socket becomes the primary driver of current).

### Preventing PhysicalÂ Attacks

The Lattice is designed to withstand many different attacks, but for this article letâ€™s focus on physical attacks. There are a few different types, which are covered in [this paper](https://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/\~mgk25/sc99-tamper.pdf), but the most important one is called a â€œ**probing attack**â€, where an attacker might disassemble a device and put secure components very close to a high powered microscope, attempting to read data from active memory (but also sometimes from persistent storage). A more sophisticated version is to use a very fine drill to bore into the device, fill the hole(s) with metal, and then perform the probing process from further away. In both cases the component generally needs to be powered to read much of anything. It is also worth mentioning that chip makers are aware of these attacks and usually put in some protections to make data harder to read when these chips are locked (as your smartcard chip always is without the PIN).

The Latticeâ€™s security mesh encases the secure microcontroller (which runs firmware + stores secure data) and on-board smartcard (which holds your Lattice wallet seed). In combination with firmware, the mesh can prevent physical attacks by **ensuring that the device has never been disassembled or tampered with**. If an attacker wishes to disassemble the device and access secure components, the mesh must be physically separated from the battery, which breaks the circuit. Furthermore, a drill would need to be <5mm, have perfect alignment, and access many important physical memory locations without grazing a single mesh circuit wireâ€Šâ€”â€Šthis would need to be done in one attempt, making it effectively impossible.

### Tamper Events

If the circuit of your security mesh is broken for more than \~100ms, it will register what we call a â€œ**tamper event**â€. When this occurs, an important region of flash memory called the **one-time programmable (OTP) region** is erased by the mesh. This region is responsible for holding **root system entropy**â€” if you lose this entropy, you will lose access to all secure data (which is encrypted using a derived key) and the PIN needed to unlock your Lattice wallet (which is derived in-memory). If a tamper event is ever encountered, data in the OTP region will be zeroed out **regardless of whether the device is powered or not**.Â 

> ***NOTE:*** *When you setup your Lattice, you are asked to create a â€œSystem PINâ€. This is **not** the PIN that unlocks your Lattice walletâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat PIN is generated in-memory from your system entropy. We do this to ensure you donâ€™t brick an expensive hardware wallet with 3 wrong PIN attempts. Instead, there is a timer with an exponential delay, allowing you to (eventually) try your PIN a few extra times and reset the system safely if you actually forget itâ€Šâ€”â€Šnote that this deletes your Lattice wallet, so you should probably have that backed up!*

As the name implies, this entropy erasure is **permanent**â€Šâ€”â€Šthe OTP region cannot be re-initialized without erasing all data from the hardware and doing a full factory reset, which requires a GridPlus ECDSA key. Once root entropy is lost, the system will be unable to boot; the device is â€œpermanently lockedâ€ and therefore unusable.Â 

![System entropy is lost and the device is bricked.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_6IIWBaOF8XdFiLDslecQ.png?height=337&width=329)

It is important to note that **a tamper event does not necessarily mean an attacker has tried to gain entry into your Lattice device**. In fact, most of the time it will **not** derive from an attackerâ€™s intrusion attempt, but will be the result of:

1. A manufacturing assembly defect or imperfection related to **alignment of the contact pads**, which close the circuit with the battery (see photo below). Lattices cannot leave the factory if the mesh circuit is broken, but they *can* register a complete circuit with slightly misaligned pads. As a result, these devices have overly sensitive meshes whose circuit can be erroneously tripped without much effort (e.g. during shipping). A small number of devices are assembled with misaligned pads and while we have improved these yields, there will always be defects (just like with any manufactured product). These cases are covered by an exchange/refund/discount policy.
2. A **significant disturbance** to the device, such as a large drop onto a hard surface or overly aggressive handling of the device such as squeezing the sides with a lot of force, or disassembly. Even a very short disturbance (\~100ms) is enough to trigger a tamper event.
3. A **fully discharged** battery (5â€“25 years, depending on operation).

<image of contact pads>

> ***NOTE:*** *Most of these non-attack-based tamper events are only temporary circuit breaks (brief lifting of contacts from pads) and can largely be remediated with a longer delay to register a tamper event. GridPlus intends to increase this delay but will not be able to do so in the short term because it requires a hardware change.*

### Arming and Disarming the Security Mesh (v0.15.0)

The above section describes how a triggered security mesh locks the Lattice, destroying the system entropy and rendering the device permanently unusable. This is a pretty intense security system and may be overkill for users who arenâ€™t worried about strike teams breaking into their home, stealing their Lattice, and putting it under a scanning electron microscope. Furthermore, it means Lattices that show up with a misaligned, triggered mesh will not be usable, even with SafeCards (which do not require secure data to operate).

To dial back the intensity, we added the ability to configure your security mesh in firmware [v0.15.0](https://github.com/GridPlus/lattice-firmware-history#v0150). **If you are an existing user updating your device**, your system will create a new configuration file once it boots. After unlocking your system, you must choose to either **arm** or **disarm** the mesh before you can use your Lattice again.

![Security mesh configuration screen](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B3T5R5M8bZfti1u4hMY5c.png?height=546&width=340)

If you choose to *arm* your mesh, the system **will function exactly the same as previously described**â€Šâ€”â€Ša tamper event will still wipe the only copy of system entropy from OTP and the system will still fail to boot. If instead you choose to *disarm *the mesh, the system entropy\* will be copied from OTP to a file (note: this one is *unencrypted*) and that will be used instead. This means if you encounter a tamper event, you can keep using the device because your entropy was backed up as part of the disarming process.

> *\* Technically we do not copy the system entropy itself, but rather 32 bytes of deterministic random data from it. Thatâ€™s fine for our purposes.*

If you change your mind, you may arm (erase copied entropy) or disarm (back up entropy) at any time in system settings. However, i**f your device encountered a tamper event while disarmed, you** **will never be able to arm it.** If you choose to keep your mesh disarmed, you may wish to periodically try re-arming it to see if there was a tamper event. If your device hasnâ€™t moved and fails to arm, this is more likely to indicate actual tampering.

### Why would I disarm myÂ mesh?

Although disarming the mesh does make your device more susceptible to physical attacks, some users may wish to do it some of the time. Reasons may include:

* If you are traveling/moving and have your Lattice on you, disarming the mesh will guarantee you can use your Lattice when you plug it in again.
* If you only use [SafeCards](https://gridplus.io/products/safe-cards) and donâ€™t care to put much (or any) value on your Lattice wallet, disarming wonâ€™t change your risk profile much.
* If you have young children who are always throwing stuff around and you arenâ€™t worried about stealthy ninjas breaking into your room, disarming may give you peace of mind.

With all this said, I want to stress for a second time that **if you arm the mesh and never disarm it, your security profile is exactly the same as it was beforeâ€Šâ€”**â€Ša tamper event will still erase all data and make your device unusable**.**

### Receiving a newÂ Lattice

Starting with the next production run, Lattices should arrive with v0.15.0 (or above) already installed and the mesh **unconfigured**. In this special state, entropy will be backed up to ensure the device is not dead-on-arrival, but you will be forced to either arm or disarm the mesh before you can use the device.

We recommend **all users arm the mesh once during new device setup** to ensure no tamper event was registered. If you are able to arm your mesh, it means your device has not been tampered with and is unlikely to have a factory defect (though the latter is still possible and may happen later). At this point, you may disarm the mesh if you wish.


---

We hope this feature gives some useful optionality to Lattice users and that this article was helpful in articulating whatâ€™s going on under the hood. With an armed mesh, your Lattice is by far the most advanced hardware wallet on the market, and even with the mesh disarmed it still has a host of both software and hardware security features that make it an extremely secure device. To arm or not to arm, the choice is yours.

title: Behind the NFT: Alex Majoliâ€™s Guards Inside the Kremlin
body:
### Magnum 75 #21 by Alex Majoli. Moscow, Russia. 2019

[https://foundation.app/@magnumphotos/mpa75/21](https://foundation.app/@magnumphotos/mpa75/21)

In 2019, Alex Majoli traveled to Moscow, Russia to explore the city and document life in the Russian capital. One of the spaces he visited was the Kremlin, and this image above shows Kremlin guards lined up in uniform.

The project was part of the Magnum Live Lab initiative, which invites photographers to spend an intense two-week period in a host city, where they produce new work and take part in daily editing sessions.

> For Alex Majoli, the concept of the Live Lab suited him: â€œTo me, the Live Lab is a beautiful idea because we can have long-term projects and edit and re-edit and all this time to think. The fact we donâ€™t have time to think, thereâ€™s an immediate response â€“ thereâ€™s an essence of truth.â€

The photographer used the opportunity to continue exploring the theatrical approach that he had developed over ten years, demonstrated in photobooks such as *Scene*. Each day, he explored a facet of Moscow that he had a preconception of, ending with an editing session with curator Nina Gomiashvili.

> Though he had visited Moscow before his recent trip for the Live Lab, Alex Majoliâ€™s vision of the city had been built through literature and music, and this guided his eye when he hit the streets daily for an intense two-week shooting and editing project. â€œWhen I walk in the city of Moscow, I have the Bulgakov black cat in my mind,â€ he says of imagining every black cat he sees in the city could be the Behemoth from the novel The Master and Margarita.

This mode of exploring, looking for motifs we recognize from our own cultural reference points, is something we all do, says Majoli. â€œAn image will stimulate something already in you and develop,â€ he explains. â€œIn that sense, art is created in people.â€

To find out more about Alex Majoliâ€™s Moscow project, check out the full article here.

To find out more about Alex Majoli, click [here](https://www.magnumphotos.com/photographer/alex-majoli/)

title: Another EMBRANDT Sounds Mix
body:
I put together a mix as a celebration of the start of summer and beating my creative block ğŸ‘ haha! Itâ€™s a great feeling to be back in the sun rays and the cold air-conditioned buildings of the city. Biking around for the first time has been fun, too. It significantly expanded my range of travel without a car and itâ€™s great cardio. The best part is summer is just getting started. 

I wanted to share what I was feeling lately in the music Iâ€™ve been listening to; this mix is a representation of a bigger playlist of about 60 songs. I take my time exploring our SoundCloud and [Audius](https://audius.co/embrandtsounds) feeds and add my favorite tunes to a playlist. From there, I listen to the playlist as I add to it and feel for a vibe in the songs. 

Whether itâ€™s the algorithm feeding me the vibes or my honest interpretation of all the music I hear, I hope you enjoy the sounds. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022)

More on how I think about and how I make my mixes below.

Tracklist: Artist - Song

 1. [Deeper Purpose - Stop Trippin](https://soundcloud.com/deeperpurpose/stop-trippin)
 2. [Sliipow - Flashion](https://soundcloud.com/terminalunderground/flashion)
 3. [Born DIrty - Kiss](https://soundcloud.com/borndirtymusic/kiss-way-way-records)
 4. [Gustavo Koch - In Da Ghetto](https://soundcloud.com/housixrecords/gustavo-koch-in-da-ghetto-hsx004)
 5. [KZN - THE CLUB](https://soundcloud.com/blackartelrec/kzn-the-club)
 6. [Mochakk - Early Synths](https://soundcloud.com/mochakkmusic/mochakk-early-synths)
 7. [Taiki Nulight - Ugly Truth](https://soundcloud.com/confession/taiki-nulight-ugly-truth)
 8. [Twista - Overnight Celebrity (Qlank Remix)](https://soundcloud.com/qlank/twista-overnight-celebrity-qlank-remix)
 9. [Twogangs - Turma](https://soundcloud.com/goodtimesaheadmusic/twogangs-turma)
10. [Victor Cardenas & Meluchis - Boom Pa-Ra (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/fightclvb/boom-pa-ra)
11. [Doja Cat - Kiss Me Moreft. SZA (Gabe Ruth Rework)](https://soundcloud.com/gaberuthau/doja-cat-kiss-me-more-ft-sza-gabe-ruth-rework)
12. [Nicche - Metro](https://soundcloud.com/nicchefm/nicche-metroo)
13. [Buogo - Free](https://soundcloud.com/houseofhustle/hls339-buogo-free-original-mix)
14. [Destinyâ€™s Child - Lose My Breath (Alex Chapman House Edit)](https://soundcloud.com/alexchapman1/lose-my-breath-alex-chapman-edit)
15. [SNBRN - DMs ft. 1993, Lucati](https://soundcloud.com/snbrn/dms-feat-1993) 
16. [Kyle Walker - All You Need (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/kylewalkersongs/all-you-need-extended-mix)
17. [Endor - Heavyweight](https://soundcloud.com/endortracksuk/heavyweight)

### Mix Method-ology  |||  Whatâ€™s to a mix by me?

I like to think of myself as a music curator and not a DJ. 

A DJ is someone that knows how to use a mixer to move a crowd with music theyâ€™ve made or gathered.

Iâ€™m generally not interested in DJing in front of people (â€¦yet. Iâ€™m on the path to convincing myself to do it). Partly because Iâ€™m still kinda shy about it, but mostly because I like to play music *I like* for people. 

Itâ€™s more of a performance. 

We all go to festivals or shows and we take in the music they play out. Granted, the music they play is stuff they make themselves and they're all usually bangers. What matters most, from my perspective, is the quality of the music they play and less about how they mix it. 

In my quest to make a mix, I prioritize the diversity of sounds and bass over everything. I focus on finding some good sounds and let the rest come together. Songs nowadays are getting creative in their intros/outros/breakdowns; I use this idea to let me bypass getting too deep into effects and instead try to find good places to press play on the next song as clean as possible (though it may not always work out that way haha).

**How do you find music?** I follow a ton of people on [SoundCloud](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/following) so my feed is all over the place with different genres and tunes a day. I can press play and I trust Iâ€™ll hear a good song at least once every 2-4 songs. 

**What do you do when you find a song you like?** There are three options: like, repost, or playlist. I repost the ones I find more creative (aka nasty) and Iâ€™ll playlist the ones I enjoyed best from those. 

**What kind of playlists do you have?** We have our main [house](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_dance) and [dubstep](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_bass) playlists, a [Halloween](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/spoopy) dubstep playlist, [trippy bass sounds](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/trippy-edm) playlist. Depending on the song, Iâ€™ll add it to one of these playlists or Iâ€™ll only throw it into my mix playlist ğŸ˜ˆ haha. Kind of evil when my spirit is to share all the music, but thatâ€™s why I want to make these posts and include the link to the huge playlist so you can see where my ears were at. 

**Drop the link to the playlist!** Say less. Hereâ€™s the pool of music I worked with for the mix. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus)

**Why are some transitions bad (or too obvious) in your mixes?** I record my mixes in one take to simulate playing in front of people. I get the most practice playing the mix when I put the songs in order; the later half of my mixes are usually more freeform in terms of how theyâ€™re put together, whereas the first half is the more practiced bit. I mix with what Iâ€™ve picked up in the last year and the goal is to learn more tricks on the mixer now that Iâ€™m happy with the way Iâ€™m putting songs together. Itâ€™s a process and Iâ€™m happy to be documenting the progress. If youâ€™ve listened to one or all of the mixes Iâ€™ve made to date, know that youâ€™re early and itâ€™s only up from here with the quality.

title: El fin de los registros
body:
Cada vez que agarramos el celular estamos perdiendo dinero. Estamos brindando atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n voluntariamente a alguna compaÃ±Ã­a privada que luego la explota, manipula y monetiza sin nuestro consentimiento. Cada plataforma es dueÃ±a de toda nuestra informaciÃ³n digital y no podemos ejercer ningÃºn derecho sobre ella.

En la internet que conocemos los bancos digitales modernos (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft y Amazon) aprovecharon el timing y sus recursos ilimitados de fondos de inversiÃ³n para ofrecernos conveniencia a cambio de nuestra atenciÃ³n e informaciÃ³n. Es exactamente lo mismo que hacen los bancos con nuestro dinero. Sus valuaciones son directamente proporcionales a la informaciÃ³n que almacenan.

Por suerte web3 cambia el paradigma. En esta nueva era los usuarios tienen el control de su informaciÃ³n, no existen bases de datos centralizadas que se puedan vender o explotar. *No se requiere completar inÃºtiles formularios de registros*.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y crypto ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Toda la informaciÃ³n de cada app que utilicemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierte en parte de nuestra identidad. Otros servicios que usemos podrÃ­an ofrecernos algo en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos por ejemplo, pero solo si elegimos comenzar sesiÃ³n con nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n y el valor econÃ³mico que se genera este mejor distribuido entre sus participantes.

title: The end of signups
body:
Every time we grab the cell phone we are losing money. We are voluntarily providing our attention and information to some private company which then exploits, manipulates and monetizes it without our consent. Each platform owns all of our digital information and we cannot exercise any rights over it.

On the internet that we know, modern digital banks (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon) took advantage of timing and their unlimited resources of investment funds to offer us convenience (cheap software) in exchange for our attention and information. Their valuations are directly proportional to the information they store. It is very similar to Banks in the sense that they control and exploit our money. 

Luckily web3 changes the paradigm. In this new era, users have control of their information, there are no centralized databases that can be sold or exploited. No need to fill out useless registration forms.

For example [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) is trying to bridge web2 and crypto by offering interfaces to integrate wallets authentication with traditional applications. The wallet implies that our information is public, portable and protected by cryptography. If we interact with a certain network or dapp the accumulated information is ours and we can use it in a new network just by logging into it.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OCLBY965FLmYkhASwMRxU.png?height=1206&width=2326)

The [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) team created a specific protocol for human digital networks that allows developers to program decentralized applications with basic social functionalities such as uploading content (posts), sharing, likes, creating your profile and generating connections (the social graph). Theoretically, networks like Twitter or Instagram could be built on Lens. All the information of each app that we use will be associated with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B4XP1C5EXSIrE5TViJbZk.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) issues an NFT (a Poap) for every event we attend. The Poap remains in our wallet and therefore it becomes part of our identity. If we choose to log in with our wallet into other applications they could offer us something based on the type of events or communities that we attend.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a9LHxknamU_7Usi24QEO1.png?height=814&width=2198)

It will be interesting to see how technology evolves in the social & identity. Undoubtedly, better applications and digital networks will be generated where users participate with rights over their information and the economic value generated is better distributed among its participants.

Por ejemplo [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) estÃ¡ intentando hacer un puente entre web2 y crypto ofreciendo interfaces para integrar wallets con aplicaciones tradicionales. El login con wallet implica que nuestra informaciÃ³n es pÃºblica, portable y estÃ¡ protegida por criptografÃ­a. Si interactuamos con cierta red y luego iniciamos sesiÃ³n en otra la informaciÃ³n acumulada es nuestra y podemos usarla en una nueva red.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/LNIBuciNJL9tCq8dS2vmD.png?height=1206&width=2326)

En el proyecto [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) crearon un protocolo especÃ­fico para lo social que permite a desarrolladores programar aplicaciones descentralizadas disponiendo de funcionalidades sociales bÃ¡sicas como subir contenido (posts), compartir, poner like, crear tu perfil y generar conexiones (el grafo social). TeÃ³ricamente, sobre Lens se podrÃ­an construir redes como Twitter o Instagram. Toda la informaciÃ³n de cada app que utilicemos va a quedar asociada a nuestra wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/iJteO0AD43yiWDwQ3ya7F.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) emite un NFT (un Poap) de cada evento al que asistimos. El Poap queda en nuestra wallet y por ende se convierte en parte de nuestra identidad. Si elegimos iniciar sesiÃ³n con nuestras wallets otras aplicaciones podrÃ­an ofrecernos contenido en base al tipo de eventos que asistimos y comunidades de las que somos parte.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/dm03_UPIZ932pbXbaJb3Z.png?height=814&width=2198)

Va a ser interesante ver como evoluciona la tecnologÃ­a en el Ã¡mbito social. Sin dudas que se van a generar mejores aplicaciones y redes digitales donde los usuarios participen con derechos sobre su informaciÃ³n y el valor econÃ³mico que se genera este mejor distribuido entre sus participantes.

title: Benji bis die Finger bluten!
body:
Die 2. Runde der **Rewards** fÃ¼r alle Besitzer eines **BenjiBananas [Member Passes](https://opensea.io/collection/benji-bananas-membership-pass)** wurde gestartet. Bei dieser Runde werden die Rewards nicht mehr einfach an alle Halter des Passes verteilt, sondern es werden bereits die **Erfolge im Spiel** gewertet. Du hast also immer noch die Chance dir einen [Pass der 1. Generation](https://opensea.io/collection/benji-bananas-membership-pass) zu sichern.

Somit ist **play2earn** eigentlich bereits gestartet und du kannst mit jeder Minute die du BenjiBananas spielst bereits Geld verdienen. Lass dir die Rewards der 1. Saison nicht entgehen!

### Was wird bewertet?

**Entfernung** - die lÃ¤ngste Distanz die du in einem einzigen Spiel der Saison geschafft hast

**Gesamtstrecke** - es werden alle Spiele der Saison zusammengezÃ¤hlt und die Gesamtstrecke gezÃ¤hlt

**Bananen** - wie viele Bananen wurden in der gesamten Saison gesammelt

**Spiele** - wie viele Spiele hast du in der Saison durchgefÃ¼hrt

**Welt** - die hÃ¶chste Welt die du in einem einzigen Spiel der Saison erreicht hast

Leider wissen wir noch nicht genau wie lange eine Saison dauern wird. Daher einfach so oft wie mÃ¶glich BenjiBananas spielen und Primate Token verdienen!

Die Entwickler von BenjiBananas sind sehr bemÃ¼ht ein **tolles Spielerlebnis** zu bieten und die Besitzer der PÃ¤sse zu belohnen. Wer bereits seit der VerÃ¶ffentlichung der NFT dabei ist, hat bereits einen tollen Gewinn gemacht.

title: The end of signups
body:
Every time we grab the cell phone we are losing money. We are voluntarily providing our attention and information to some private company which then exploits, manipulates and monetizes it without our consent. Each platform owns all of our digital information and we cannot exercise any rights over it.

On the internet that we know, modern digital banks (Facebook, Google, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon) took advantage of timing and their unlimited resources of investment funds to offer us convenience (cheap software) in exchange for our attention and information. Their valuations are directly proportional to the information they store. It is very similar to Banks in the sense that they control and exploit our money. 

Luckily web3 changes the paradigm. In this new era, users have control of their information, there are no centralized databases that can be sold or exploited. No need to fill out useless registration forms.

For example [Login.xyz](https://login.xyz/) is trying to bridge web2 and crypto by offering interfaces to integrate wallets authentication with traditional applications. The wallet implies that our information is public, portable and protected by cryptography. If we interact with a certain network or dapp the accumulated information is ours and we can use it in a new network just by logging into it.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OCLBY965FLmYkhASwMRxU.png?height=1206&width=2326)

The [Lens](https://lens.xyz/) team created a specific protocol for human digital networks that allows developers to program decentralized applications with basic social functionalities such as uploading content (posts), sharing, likes, creating your profile and generating connections (the social graph). Theoretically, networks like Twitter or Instagram could be built on Lens. All the information of each app that we use will be associated with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/B4XP1C5EXSIrE5TViJbZk.jpeg?height=4096&width=8192)

[POAP.xyz](https://poap.xyz/) issues an NFT (a Poap) for every event we attend. The Poap remains in our wallet and therefore it becomes part of our identity. Other products or services that we use could offer us something based on the type of events that we attend for example, but only if we choose to log in with our wallet.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a9LHxknamU_7Usi24QEO1.png?height=814&width=2198)

It will be interesting to see how technology evolves in the social field. Undoubtedly, better applications and digital networks will be generated where users participate with rights over their information and the economic value generated is better distributed among its participants.

title: IVA e Impuestos: Definiciones Clave
body:
1. Â¿QuÃ© es el Impuesto al Valor Agregado (IVA)?
   El Impuesto al Valor Agregado (IVA) es un tipo de impuesto (indirecto) que se aplica, en principio, a todas las actividades comerciales que involucran la producciÃ³n y distribuciÃ³n de bienes y la prestaciÃ³n de servicios.
2. Â¿CuÃ¡ndo se estableciÃ³ en MÃ©xico?
   Fue establecido en 1980 y sustituyÃ³ al Impuesto Sobre Ingresos Mercantiles.
3. Â¿QuÃ© impuesto reemplazÃ³ inicialmente?
   Impuesto Sobre Ingresos Mercantiles.
4. Â¿QuÃ© ley regula este impuesto?

* Ley del Impuesto al Valor Agregado o Ley del IVA.

1. Â¿CuÃ¡les son los actos o actividades contemplados en esta Ley?
   \-Cuando:
   Vender bienes.
   Proporcionar servicios independientes.
   Otorgar el uso o goce temporal de bienes inmuebles.
   Bienes o servicios importados.
2. Â¿CuÃ¡l es la tasa impositiva general?

* El 16% es el tipo impositivo general.

1. Â¿QuÃ© otras tarifas estÃ¡n contempladas?

* La ley establece el IVA para un 16%, luego un 0% para algunos productos, servicios y actividades especificados y una tasa exenta (sin impuesto) para otros productos, servicios y actividades especificados.

1. Da algunos ejemplos de productos, servicios o actividades que tributan al 0%

* Algunas cosas que estÃ¡n gravadas con una tasa del 0% son por ejemplo animales y plantas que no estÃ¡n industrializados excepto el caucho, perros, gatos y especies pequeÃ±as como mascotas en el hogar. TambiÃ©n, medicamentos de patente y productos para alimentaciÃ³n (con algunas excepciones), hielo y no elaborados con gas o agua, salvo que la presentaciÃ³n sea en envases inferiores a diez litros.

1. DÃ© algunos ejemplos de productos, servicios o actividades que no estÃ¡n sujetos a este impuesto (exentos)

* Son cosas exentas el suelo, construcciones adosadas al suelo destinadas o destinadas a habitaciÃ³n de vivienda. Libros, diarios y revistas, asÃ­ como el derecho de uso o explotaciÃ³n de una obra. Billetes y otros vales que permitan participar en loterÃ­as, rifas, sorteos o juegos.

title: Another EMBRANDT Sounds Mix
body:
I put together a mix as a celebration of the start of summer and beating my creative block ğŸ‘ haha! Itâ€™s a great feeling to be back in the sun rays and the cold air-conditioned buildings of the city. Biking around for the first time has been fun, too. It significantly expanded my range of travel without a car and itâ€™s great cardio. The best part is summer is just getting started. 

I wanted to share what I was feeling lately in the music Iâ€™ve been listening to; this mix is a representation of a bigger playlist of about 60 songs. I take my time exploring our SoundCloud and [Audius](https://audius.co/embrandtsounds) feeds and add my favorite tunes to a playlist. From there, I listen to the playlist as I add songs to it and get a feel for the sounds in the songs. 

Whether itâ€™s the algorithm feeding me the vibes or my honest interpretation of all the music I hear, I know youâ€™ll enjoy these sounds. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/summer-house-mix-2022)

(More on how I think about and how I make my mixes below.)

Tracklist: Artist - Song

 1. [Deeper Purpose - Stop Trippin](https://soundcloud.com/deeperpurpose/stop-trippin)
 2. [Sliipow - Flashion](https://soundcloud.com/terminalunderground/flashion)
 3. [Born DIrty - Kiss](https://soundcloud.com/borndirtymusic/kiss-way-way-records)
 4. [Gustavo Koch - In Da Ghetto](https://soundcloud.com/housixrecords/gustavo-koch-in-da-ghetto-hsx004)
 5. [KZN - THE CLUB](https://soundcloud.com/blackartelrec/kzn-the-club)
 6. [Mochakk - Early Synths](https://soundcloud.com/mochakkmusic/mochakk-early-synths)
 7. [Taiki Nulight - Ugly Truth](https://soundcloud.com/confession/taiki-nulight-ugly-truth)
 8. [Twista - Overnight Celebrity (Qlank Remix)](https://soundcloud.com/qlank/twista-overnight-celebrity-qlank-remix)
 9. [Twogangs - Turma](https://soundcloud.com/goodtimesaheadmusic/twogangs-turma)
10. [Victor Cardenas & Meluchis - Boom Pa-Ra (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/fightclvb/boom-pa-ra)
11. [Doja Cat - Kiss Me Moreft. SZA (Gabe Ruth Rework)](https://soundcloud.com/gaberuthau/doja-cat-kiss-me-more-ft-sza-gabe-ruth-rework)
12. [Nicche - Metro](https://soundcloud.com/nicchefm/nicche-metroo)
13. [Buogo - Free](https://soundcloud.com/houseofhustle/hls339-buogo-free-original-mix)
14. [Destinyâ€™s Child - Lose My Breath (Alex Chapman House Edit)](https://soundcloud.com/alexchapman1/lose-my-breath-alex-chapman-edit)
15. [SNBRN - DMs ft. 1993, Lucati](https://soundcloud.com/snbrn/dms-feat-1993) 
16. [Kyle Walker - All You Need (Extended Mix)](https://soundcloud.com/kylewalkersongs/all-you-need-extended-mix)
17. [Endor - Heavyweight](https://soundcloud.com/endortracksuk/heavyweight)

### Mix Method-ology  ||  Whatâ€™s to a mix?

I like to think of myself as a music curator and not a DJ. 

A DJ is someone that can use a controller or mixer to play their music to move a crowd at a social gathering.

A music curator looks for hit music, new music, or underground music to play for an audience. 

Iâ€™m generally not interested in DJing in front of people (â€¦yet. Iâ€™m on the path to convincing myself to do it). Partly because Iâ€™m still kinda shy about it, but mostly because I like to play music *I like* for people. 

Itâ€™s more of a performance. And documentation of my progress.

We all go to festivals or shows and we take in the music they play out. Granted, the music they play is stuff they make themselves and they're all usually bangers. What matters most, from my perspective, is the quality of the music they play and less about how they mix it. 

In my quest to make a mix, I prioritize the diversity of sounds and bass over everything. I focus on finding some good sounds and let the rest come together. Songs nowadays are getting creative in their intros/outros/breakdowns; I use this idea to let me bypass getting too deep into effects and instead try to find good places to press play on the next song as clean as possible (though it may not always work out that way haha).

**How do you find music?** I follow a ton of people on [SoundCloud](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/following) so my feed is all over the place with different genres and tunes a day. I can press play and I trust Iâ€™ll hear a good song at least once every 2-4 songs. 

**What do you do when you find a song you like?** There are three options: like, repost, or playlist. I repost the ones I find more creative (aka nasty) and Iâ€™ll playlist the ones I enjoyed best from those. 

**What kind of playlists do you have?** We have our main [house](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_dance) and [dubstep](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/embrandt_bass) playlists, a [Halloween](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/spoopy) dubstep playlist, [trippy bass sounds](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/trippy-edm) playlist. Depending on the song, Iâ€™ll add it to one of these playlists or Iâ€™ll only throw it into my mix playlist ğŸ˜ˆ haha. Kind of evil when my spirit is to share all the music, but thatâ€™s why I want to make these posts and include the link to the huge playlist so you can see where my ears were at. 

**Drop the link to the playlist!** Say less. Hereâ€™s the pool of music I worked with for the mix. 

[https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus](https://soundcloud.com/embrandtsounds/sets/more-haus)

**Why are some transitions bad (or too obvious) in your mixes?** I record my mixes in one take to simulate playing in front of people. I get the most practice playing the mix when I put the songs in order; the later half of my mixes are usually more freeform in terms of how theyâ€™re put together, whereas the first half is the more practiced bit. I mix with what Iâ€™ve picked up in the last year and the goal is to learn more tricks on the mixer now that Iâ€™m happy with the way Iâ€™m putting songs together. Itâ€™s a process and Iâ€™m happy to be documenting the progress. If youâ€™ve listened to one or all of the mixes Iâ€™ve made to date, know that youâ€™re early and itâ€™s only up from here with the quality.
